results.title: NOISE on film: noise for Darfur = Why should Australians make noise for Darfur?
results.creator_credit: Darfur Australia Network and Infinite Films
results.brief_description:
This documentary has been produced to raise awareness about the continuing tragedy in the Darfur region of Western Sudan and build solidarity between the Australian people and the people of Darfur.
The conflict in Darfur has been continuing for more than three years, has resulted in the deaths of more than 400,000 civilians, the displacement of at least 2.5 million people and there are currently 3.5 million people dependent upon insufficient international humanitarian aid. Darfur is in crisis and the genocide has to stop.
The film includes footage from refugee camps in Darfur, artwork and music from a range of local artists, and the perceptions of a range of influential Australians as to why Australians should make NOISE for Darfur.

results.title: Queenscliff beaches; Our journey
results.creator_credit: Paul Jones and Queenscliff Primary School
results.brief_description:
This film is a learning outcome from the “Beaches” group student led investigation program at Queenscliff Primary School. It was undertaken as part of the 2007 Snapshots of Remote Communities Project and was overall winner of the Annual Sprockets and Flares Multimedia Awards.
A combination of softwares including Blue Sky technologies and artwork by the students was used in the creation of this work.
Two versions are included:
1. Queenscliff beaches - final product
2. Our journey - details the behind-the-scenes and process

results.title: Billie in Oakleigh
results.brief_description:
A short home-movie shot in slow-motion of the graceful and elegant movements of Billie O’Keefe as she performs a gymnastic routine in the urban landscape of Oxford Street, Oakleigh.
This poetic film is backed by the haunting soundtrack of celtic music played by Cath Connelly (harp) and Greg Hunt (fiddle).

results.title: One another
results.brief_description:
Two protagonists search for themselves/each other within morphing boundaries and shifting skies.
Charcoal drawing on erasure stop frame animation with live action video.
Music composed by Joseph Tawadros and performed by Joseph Tawadros, James Tawadros and Ben Rodgers.

results.title: Blokes and sheds
results.creator_credit: Robi Watt, Sarah Wishart, Australian Film Commission, SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation and Mark Thomson
results.brief_description:
The backyard shed is an Australian icon. It may appear, to the unenlightened, to be a tacked-together corrugated iron structure full of junk, nails and spiders. In truth, it has become a peculiarly Australian horde of stories and myths about isolation, masculinity, identity, capability, self esteem, tradition and even passionate obsession. It is history on a very human scale, a one-person size record of a life. There is a mystery to a shed, with dark corners; yet grace, too in odd and unexpected ways. By talking to the owners and occupiers of twelve vastly diverse sheds all over South Australia, ‘Blokes and Sheds’ casts a gentle enquiring light into those cobwebbed nooks and crannies to tease out many paradoxes and passions. Each shed is the setting for its owner to open their hearts and share their stories in these twelve, two-minute documentaries.
Based on the book by Mark Thomson.

results.title: Richmond 150 years on
results.brief_description: Inner city Richmond (Victoria) celebrates its 150th birthday. Local residents, shop-keepers, community leaders including Ian “Molly” Meldrum and Peter Norden have their say about their beloved Richmond. Whether born there or a recent newcomer, Richmond it seems, is a place of community, fierce loyalty and respect for your neighbour. Includes some wonderful images of past and present including the MCG, Punt Road, Bridge Road, Swan Street, remains of old factories such as Rosella and archival stills of local street scenes. Narrated by Rob Clancy.

results.title: Common ground: Youth Summit 2006
results.brief_description:
‘Youth summit 2006’ is an inspirational collection of works from young people who, through their association with the Western Chances program, have been given the opportunity to tell their stories and build their own bridge to the future. Common Ground is part of the First Person: International Digital Storytelling Conference.
Western Chances was established to ensure that financial hardship does not prevent a young person in Melbourne’s West from achieving their maximum potential in life.
